content:
Hey all! :wave: So I regularly forget to release new versions of things or even what state things are in, so I had a half-baked thought of trying to process our way out of it a bit by:

  • Having a sync up on where a bunch of libs are at at the start of Rust's 6-week release cycle
  • Automating publishing those libs to crates.io by PRing main to release
  • Have a release-a-thon for all the libs towards the end of Rust's 6-week release cycle

What do you all think? Would anybody be interested in meeting a bit more regularly to catch up on all the libraries and RFCs and things we care about?

@DPC you might be interested in this :point_of_information:
I definitely think we should be meeting more regularly.
The 2 weeks that we used to do seemed a bit often, but maybe once every 6 weeks would be enough?
That sounds good to me. We can always adjust upwards!
Definitely interested :stuck_out_tongue: I like the idea though I'm not sure whether we should automate the releases or not
@DPC We don’t necessarily have to publish automatically :slight_smile: It would be a little more busy work to keep track of, but with a list to work off it shouldn’t be too bad

Is sometime next week too short notice for everyone? Maybe it would be worth meeting first to look at broad things, where some of the RFCs are at, anything we’ve got in the works that could benefit from some input, any project groups we think should exist, how the sharing of standard library implementation with the compiler is going?
Can I join too? I never join any meetings and I wonder how it is.
I would be interested too
Sure! The more the merrier :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes: @Jane Lusby would you be interested too? Did we ever properly spin up a project group for you?
I haven't submitted the proposal yet. I've been spending most of my free time recently working on my rustconf talk, but I hope to have all the paperwork done soon.
so not yet
That’s right! It’s coming up next month

I think next week might be too short. Given that you are in a timezone which is almost half a day ahead :stuck_out_tongue: how about sending a doodle to everyone so we can pick a time suitable for most? :grinning:
I wonder if @lzutao is interested as well.
That’s a good idea :+1: I’ll make a scratch doc with the next few weeks on it
So I guess there’s also the meta question of whether we’re still really “libs” or whether we’re more “standards”

pickfire said:

I wonder if lzutao is interested as well.

Not sure what is this topic about?
Joining a lib team meeting about release cycle and other things
Thanks. But release cycle of which libraries/crates/things?

Hey all! :wave: So I regularly forget to release new versions of things or even what state things are in, so I had a half-baked thought of trying to process our way out of it a bit by:

  • Having a sync up on where a bunch of libs are at at the start of Rust's 6-week release cycle
  • Automating publishing those libs to crates.io by PRing main to release
  • Have a release-a-thon for all the libs towards the end of Rust's 6-week release cycle

What do you all think? Would anybody be interested in meeting a bit more regularly to catch up on all the libraries and RFCs and things we care about?
(From @Ashley Mannix)

So we are publishing the libs to crates, does that mean we could easily clone and build them without building rust-lang/rust itself? If that's the case, then it would be interesting, I wish the building time for libs can be reduced.
